item.title: CS152-lecture-20210706
item.description: Tweakable block ciphers # The idea is that our block cipher \( E \) will take our key, and a second input called a tweak. \[\begin{aligned} \tilde{E}:(\text{key, tweak}) \to \left( \{0,1\}^b \to \{0,1\}^b \right) \end{aligned}\] We notate that the block cipher is tweakable via the tilde notation, \( \tilde{E} \) . The key must be random and private, but the tweak is non-random and public.
